title.narrative: Mechanism 14441 - Center of Excellence for Comprehensive Integrated HIV Care and Treatment Services in Lilongwe, Malawi

description.narrative:
Additional detail on PEPFAR financial information and terminology can be found at https://data.pepfar.gov/financial. The PEPFAR IATI activity file and PEPFAR IATI Activity File User's Guide can be found at https://data.pepfar.gov/additionalData
IMPACT: This mechanism is designed to assist with the scale-up of high quality and innovative HIV treatment services at Lighthouse, and through demonstrating new service delivery and integration models, is also designed to improve the quality and efficiency of HIV treatment services nationally. The Lighthouse is the largest single provider of integrated HIV services in Malawi, supporting over 25,0 Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.6: Adult Care and Support. All facility-based and home/community-based activities for HIV-infected adults and their families aimed at extending and optimizing quality of life for HIV-infected clients and their families throughout the continuum of illness through provision of clinical, psychological, spiritual, social and prevention services. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.12: Laboratory Infrastructure. Development and strengthening of laboratory systems and facilities to support HIV/AIDSrelated activities including purchase of equipment and commodities and provision of quality assurance, staff training and other technical assistance. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.11: Treatment/Adult Treatment. Including infrastructure, training clinicians and other providers, exams, clinical monitoring, related laboratory services, and community-adherence activities. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.2: Sexual Prevention - Abstinence/Be Faithful. Activities (including training) to promote abstinence, fidelity, reducing multiple and concurrent partners, and related social and community norms that impact these behaviors. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.9: Counseling and Testing. Includes activities in which both HIV counseling and testing are provided for those who seek to know their HIV status (as in traditional VCT) or provider initiated counseling and testing. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.5: Sexual Prevention - Other Sexual Prevention. Other activities (including training) aimed at preventing HIV transmission including purchase and promotion of condoms, STI management (if not in palliative care settings/context), messages/programs to reduce other risks of persons engaged in high-risk behaviors. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.14: Strategic Information. HIV/AIDS behavioral and biological surveillance, facility surveys, monitoring partner results, reporting results, supporting health information systems, assisting countries to establish and/or strengthen such systems, and related analysis and data dissemination activities fall under strategic information. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.7: TB/HIV. Includes exams, clinical monitoring, related laboratory services, treatment and prevention of tuberculosis (including medication), as well as screening and referral of TB clinic clients for HIV testing and clinical care. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.1: Preventing Mother-to-Child Transmission (PMTCT). Activities (including training) aimed at preventing mother-to-child HIV transmission, including ARV prophylaxis for HIV-infected pregnant women and newborns and counseling and support for maternal nutrition. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.13: Health System Strengthening. Include activities that contribute to national, regional or district level systems by supporting finance, leadership and governance (include broad policy reform efforts including stigma, gender, etc.), institutional capacity building, supply chain or procurement systems, Global Fund programs and donor coordination. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.17: Pediatric Care and Support. All health facility-based care for HIV-exposed children and their families aimed at extending and optimizing quality of life for HIV-infected clients and their families throughout the continuum of illness through provision of clinical, psychological, spiritual, social and prevention services. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.18: Treatment/Pediatric Treatment. Including infrastructure, training clinicians and other providers, exams, clinical monitoring, related laboratory services, and community-adherence activities. objectives

IMPACT: This mechanism is designed to assist with the scale-up of high quality and innovative HIV treatment services at Lighthouse, and through demonstrating new service delivery and integration models, is also designed to improve the quality and efficiency of HIV treatment services nationally. The Lighthouse is the largest single provider of integrated HIV services in Malawi, supporting over 25,000 PLHIV. It provides tertiary level referral services at two clinic sites: the first clinic, opened at Kamuzu Central Hospital in 2002, and subsequently the Martin Preuss Centre (MPC) established in 2006 at Bwaila Hospital. MPC integrates ART with TB service delivery at the largest TB treatment site in Malawi and supports the provision of Option B+ services at the Bwaila Maternity Unit, the highest volume maternity unit in Malawi. It has been designated a National Training Center by the MOH and certifies providers in HIV testing and counseling (HTC), palliative care and ART provision. Lighthouse program models inform national policy and provide operational guidance to improve the quality and efficiency of integrated treatment, care and support for HIV service delivery and facility and community level. The partner collaboratively pioneered the development of an Electronic Data System (EDS), which has since been rolled out to over 40 of the higher burden ART sites nationally, with further roll-out planned. It has also launched an innovative program aimed at reducing defaulters and improving long-term retention in ART treatment through active tracing and follow-up. Lighthouse was also one of the three sites chosen to pilot routine viral load screening, and is currently using its lessons learned to help coordinate the roll-out to over 70 sites nationally.

mailing-address.narrative: 1800 G Street, N.W., Suite 10300, Washington, DC 20006

policy-marker.narrative: The U.S. President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR) is the U.S. government's response to the global HIV/AIDS epidemic and represents the largest commitment by any nation to address a single disease in history.
